title: Comcast Spectator Announces 'Philadelphia Fusion' Team for Overwatch League
body:
Owner of the Philadelphia Flyers, Comcast Spectator, has opted in for the Overwatch League with the hefty $20 million per team franchise. Much like many of the other investors in the Overwatch League, this is Comcast Spectator's first eSports venture, but they are certainly no stranger to sports in general. That's because Comcast Spectator is an entirely sports-based organization. Founded in 1974, the organization has over 40 years of experience in the industry managing not only sports teams, but also arenas (such as the Wells Fargo Center) and sports broadcasting networks (previously owned Comcast SportsNet regional sports networks). author: Nate Chrisman
title: IOC Wants eSports Treated the Same as Traditional Sports... and They Should
body:
Not more than two months ago, news had become known about the International Olympic Committee (IOC) taking eSports into consideration for future olympic games. Despite the Asian Games in Hangzhou in 2022 including eSports, the president of the IOC, Thomas Bach, still wants to proceed with caution and not promise too much in terms of acceptance into future games. It seemed that the main concerns fall in the realms of: 1. A complete regulatory organization 2. Content of the games that would be played In terms of wanting a complete regulatory organization, that is entirely understandable. Bach had said himself that “You have to have somebody who is guaranteeing you that these athletes doing video sports games are not doped, that they are following technical rules, that they are respecting each other.” This is entirely reasonable when you would be talking not only about Olympic level competition in sports, but also in any competition that requires the entrants are held to the highest standard. The recent Olympic Summit, which was held on October 28, 2017, dedicated part of their time to talking about eSports. From the olympic.org website, there are a few important things to note that were said that show progress on this front:
  • eSports are showing strong growth, especially within the youth demographic across different countries, and can provide a platform for engagement with the Olympic Movement.
  • Competitive "eSports" could be considered as a sporting activity, and the players involved prepare and train with an intensity which may be comparable to athletes in traditional sports.
  • In order to be recognised by the IOC as a sport, the content of "eSports" must not infringe on the Olympic values.
  • A further requirement for recognition by the IOC must be the existence of an organisation guaranteeing compliance with the rules and regulations of the Olympic Movement (anti-doping, betting, manipulation, etc.).
As for the content of the games, that might be a more difficult thing to regulate seeing as they are trying to capture a younger demographic as a result of eSports inclusion. There have been talks of only including games that are analogous to traditional sports (such as basketball, football, etc.), which do not contain any violence, mature content, etc. This, they have said, would be more in line with the Olympic values. However, it does still seem like they are starting to change their opinion more as time goes on. Even if eSports do not end up being included in the Olympic Games by the IOC, it doesn't seem that it would inhibit the eSports industry's growth.

title: Players Receive Lifetime Ban from Canada Cup
body:
On one of the final stops for the CPT this year, Canada Cup in Toronto ran into some issues regarding the Marvel vs. Capcom: Infinite competition. According to Canada Cup representatives, "Quackbot" (Jose Aldape), who also goes by PC Marvel God, had entered the tournament twice, first under his original alias, and then under another player's alias after being eliminated. The second player involved was "Holy Order Troll" (Lina Crawford), who had given her spot to him as a result of an apparent stick malfunction. This had caused many matches to be replayed in the bracket in order to remedy the issue. Quackbot issued an apology on Twitter for what happened.
A statement released by Canada Cup officials states that "With no prior precedent of this in our community, Tournament Organizers were required to make a judgement call quickly for all players impacted". The decision that was made resulted in both players being banned from the event indefinitely. Canada Cup officials concluded the statement by saying "Players who misrepresent themselves under another player’s gamertag or multiple gamertags (with and without consent) undermine the legitimacy of tournament events, and are in violation of the rules." title: Overwatch Spectator Mode Enhancements
body:
Spectating in Overwatch is getting some new features which should allow for a more enjoyable spectator experience. One of the biggest gripes I've had with watching Overwatch is it felt way too chaotic.  It felt like the viewer never had a good view of all the action happening around them and it was difficult to figure out which team one was looking at.  With the new updates incoming (just in time for the Overwatch World Cup) most, if not all of those complaints will be erased.

Teams will now be required to use team colors making it easier for spectators to determine who is who without issue. Commentators  will also have access to a bird eye view of the map so viewers can see all the heroes moving in real time in a strategic view. This will help the commentators provide better feedback of what's happening in the game to enhance the spectating experience.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/AUPExXBfS1s?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

A smarter camera is going to be in place which will auto-detect where all the action is happening.  The camera view is an "over-the-shoulder" of the player being spectated giving the spectator a much wider area to view. Of course the smart camera isn't going to catch everything which provides a perfect reason to use the newly included replay feature! Whenever a big play happens duringa game, commentators will now be able to replay a segment of gameplay at a normal or slower speed to break down gameplay piece by piece. Lastly, real-time stat tracking will be provided for all players so people can determine who really is the best of the best.

I'm sure the implementation of these tools won't be perfect when they launch but it sounds like a really solid foundation for Blizzard to build upon as Overwatch grows bigger as an esport.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: Being an Esports Athlete Isn't Always Easy - Mew2King's Mental Health Struggle
body: Looking up the definition of “sport” says: “an activity involving physical exertion and skill in which an individual or team competes against another or others for entertainment.” So where is all of the exertion coming from in esports? It’s mental. That’s not to say that traditional sports don’t require mental strength and dexterity, but esports faces a more defined obstacle in the world of mental health as it becomes more of a mainstream activity and fruitful career opportunity. A recent example of this is Jason Zimmerman, who needs no introduction as Mew2King, the most decorated Super Smash Bros. player in esports history with a staggering 70 tournament wins to date. A member of Team Echo Fox, which has some of the most notable esports athletes on their roster, he is no doubt a superstar. Zimmerman spoke with ESPN recently about experiencing depression throughout the recent past and what is being done to battle it. Although he didn’t speak of the specific cause of his depression, he did say that he just trying “not to think about it”. He battles with Obsessive Compulsive Disorder as well, which can become a problem when it starts to affect your daily life. Jace Hall, the CEO of Echo Fox has been working with him through this battle. Hall said that he has “explained to him just a couple of ideas” on how to handle things, which seems to be working since his playing has been more consistent over the recent year. Hall said, "He needs tools, mental tools that he can put in his toolbox that help him process how he feels about things." With Echo Fox being owned by none other than Rick Fox, former NBA star for the Boston Celtics and Los Angeles Lakers, Zimmerman is probably in a good place for learning how to handle the mental stresses that come with being on top of your game in your industry. However, we aren't sure if that is the cause of the depression that Zimmerman has been experiencing. What is important to recognize is that in accomplishing anything difficult, there will always be some sort of struggle. It isn't easy, but we are all human and we find ways to overcome. Esports athletes who are among the best, in any game, are having to learn how to handle fame and the stresses of being in the limelight and staying on top of the competition. It certainly isn’t as easy as it might seem, and there is no question that mental health and fortitude are going to be one of the primary topics of conversation in the coming years. It does seem, however, that with the rising popularity of esports franchises among current or previous traditional sports athletes/team owners that there will be a solid foundation in place as the industry continues to grow into it’s new space.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: South Korea Faced Solid Competition 2017's Overwatch World Cup
body:
Team South Korea left trails of fire behind them as they blazed through the top 8 bracket of the Overwatch World Cup. After taking a look back at how they crushed the World Cup in 2016 by not losing a single round in the top 8, it was clear that this year’s teams needed to bring some more to the table. South Korea began their top 8 against Team USA in the quarter-finals, followed by France in the semi-finals, then Canada for the grand-finals. 

Clearly the most balanced match in terms of skill for the top 8 we saw today was against Team USA (3-1, technically 4-2 if you include the draw). With the USA starting off strong on Nepal with a win, drawing on Hanamura, and only sparingly trailing behind KR on the other maps by single points (except for the final, which was 2-0), KR found out that they actually had some serious competition this year. Team USA’s ability to adapt to KR’s extremely cohesive and effective gameplay put them on the map, although they ended up with a loss in the end. 

The semi-finals with France lasted one less match than with USA (3-1). Considering France’s strong victory against China in the quarter-finals, they put up a solid fight, following in USA’s footsteps by closely trailing KR by 1 round on every match they had together. Yet, France did not have enough to pull through with a win.

KR’s largest win in terms of margin was the grand-finals against Canada (4-1). KR did not give CA any breating room at all out of what was supposed to be 7 matches. KR cleaned house against CA by reaching 4 wins out of the first 5 that were played, having no mercy on the North American team. 

<iframe src="https://player.twitch.tv/?video=v187734567&autoplay=false" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="true" scrolling="no" height="378" width="620"></iframe>

Compared to last year’s gameplay, there is definitely an improvement all around, but KR remains supreme in being able to harness the chaos that can ensue in these matches and use it to their advantage. Out of the top 8, USA appeared to adapt the best to KR’s game, but were still followed closely by France and CA.

title: K1llsen's First Major Quake Champions Win at Italian Esports Open
body:
Marcel ‘K1llsen’ Paul took home the gold medal in Day 4 of the Quake Champions Italian Esports Open yesterday against Sander ‘Voo’ Kaasjager. With nearly 20 seconds remaining in the 4th round, K1llsen, as Doomslayer, secured himself by being aggressive against Voo and his Nyx for the kill that tied up the round with 2 frags each, taking them into overtime. K1llsen pulled through in overtime by fragging Voo again, then bringing them into the 5th and final round of the tournament where he proved himself worthy of 1st place.
Starting the 5th round with K1llsen’s Nyx and Voo’s Anarchy, both arguably the best at those champions in the game, K1llsen played extremely smart by keeping his distance from Voo and taking advantage of opportunities as they came to him, realizing that patience would prevail in the end. K1llsen took home the trophy with a 3-0 match, making him the man to beat for Dreamhack Winter this December.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: Evo Japan is ARMS’ chance to shine. Does it have what it takes?
body:
If there is one game on the market right now that is truly different than any other in it’s genre, it would be ARMS. The fighting game for Nintendo Switch seems to have a dedicated community, but does it have the chops to hold its own in the FGC on a competitive level? I think EVO Japan will be the event to reveal that answer. 

Since the release of ARMS in June of this year, it has received critiques from all angles, positive and negative. Everything from the look, mechanics, and depth of the game have been questioned in terms of whether or not it has what it takes to be a serious contender for fighting game esports. 

As for the look of the game, although it doesn’t have anything to do with the competitive nature, it is unique. In fact, it’s right in line with the type of look you’d expect from a Nintendo exclusive – smooth, cartoonish, and unlike anything else that you might want to compare it to. Each fighter in the game has a clear theme of their own. Their names, looks, and ARMS are all thought out and creates motive to find your favorite. 

One of the game’s largest critiques stems from the apparent lack of depth or veering too far off the traditional path when it comes to the mechanics of a fight, but that seems to be a little disingenuous. Those who are saying this may just be comparing the gameplay to other fighters that have rapport with the FGC, such as Street Fighter, Marvel vs. Capcom, Tekken, Guilty Gear, and other traditional titles. This can be an unfair comparison if you aren’t careful. ARMS features a 3D plane in which the camera is locked to a behind view of the fighter, which is probably the most notable difference. However, it also rewards the ability to fight your opponent at a distance, which in a fighting game with a boxing focus seems counter-intuitive. This is actually the game’s strong point, in my opinion.

Fighters use their extendable ARMS to fight their opponent. Every fighter has a unique set of ARMS that have different tools which complement the fighter’s theme/background and give the player a specialized tool set to take down their opponent. Since the ARMS extend virtually across each stage, the gameplay rewards those who are able to apply traditional fighting game techniques at a distance, such as zoning, hit confirms, etc. on a 3D plane, instead of trying to scrap with your opponent up close on a 2D plane. 

With that being said, there has been a popular view (obviously subjective) that, while the gameplay might be engaging as a player, it isn’t engaging to the spectator. So, given the 3D playing field, unique look and mechanics, the game still isn’t as interesting to a lot of people as the other, larger titles. I think that this is where the pain point lies when it comes to whether or not ARMS has what it takes to be a large title in the competitive gaming world. 

For every professional esports athlete, there are tens of thousands, even hundreds of thousands, of viewers that want to watch the game. This is where the decision is going to be made in terms of its continuance at major tournaments. At the end of the day, it is about the amount of spectators that it can bring to the table. So, it’s definitely different in a lot of areas, but is that what people are asking for? Having non-traditional features, in this case, is a double edged sword. I guess we will have to wait until EVO Japan has finished to see whether or not it will be included in EVO Las Vegas, let alone other FGC majors.

title: Talking Stick Resort in Phoenix Doubles Down on Smash Esports
body:
Ramon Martinez, director of public relations for Talking Stick Resort in Phoenix said, right before they hosted their first FGC tournament in October of this year, "eSports is the future of sports and entertainment and we are Arizona's home for it." Well, that event went off without a hitch, so they're hosting another one in what they're saying is a series of local events. So, November 18th brings a $5,000 prize pool for Smash 4 and Smash Melee competitors. Each title will have singles and doubles, and will cost you about $25 to enter the competition depending on what you want to compete in.
They've recruited Michael Udall, an Arizona local who won his tuition at Arizona State University by competing in esports. Udall's specialty is in Heroes of the Storm, but with being in the competitive gaming world for the past few years, he's probably a good person to have on their team. Is this the next big step for esports in Arizona? It seems as if the event experts at Talking Stick are all in. It wouldn't be surprising to see other titles in the near future.

author: Mike Keppler
title: New Hero and Map for Overwatch!
body:
The latest addition to the Overwatch roster is the much anticipated support healer going by the name Moira. Like Zenyatta (except polar opposite on the morality scale), Moira has the ability to provide healing to her teammates while also contributing damage to the enemy team. She can also provide healing to herself by sapping the life force from enemies using her “Biotic Grasp” command. Another unique ability in Moira’s arsenal is “Fade” which allows her to quickly teleport a short distance to easily stay close to her team or escape danger. Not only that, but she looks great especially with her community requested “Naruto-run” which got many Overwatch fans giddy with excitement. Finally, her ultimate ability “Coalescence” allows Moira to blast out a stream of healing power and damage giving her the opportunity to heal allies and damage enemies at the same time.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8tLopqeL9s8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Not only are we receiving a new hero, but a new map as well! I got a rush of feelings when the new map, Blizzard World, was announced. When Jeff Kaplan (creative director of Overwatch) was on the Mythic stage at Blizzcon during the opening ceremony, he asked the crowd how they would feel about a Blizzard amusement park.  My first thought was them announcing that they are going to build an actual amusement park (like what Nintendo is doing). After I pushed that idea out of my head, I realized that this amusement park is going to be the next map!

Serving as a hybrid map, the attacking team will have to capture a point which will unlock the payload. From this point, the attackers will have to escort the payload for the remainder of the match. What makes this map stand out is that the two teams will be fighting in Blizzard World which is an amusement park with all of Blizzard’s famous IP.  Players will fight through the Warcraft, Starcraft and Diablo universes as they push the payload to the goal line. This works since Blizzard actually exists within the world of Overwatch (in a timeline where Blizzard never developed Overwatch or else the hole would get really, really deep).

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Ii3Hce3_fOw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Moira went live on the PTR today and Blizzard World will most likely follow in the next few weeks.

title: MK Leo on Being #1: "I’m going to be the best in the world. I can and I want to"
body:
Sparkd Productions and MK Leo teamed up to give us a deeper look into the top Smash 4 player’s life, and it’s full of both hardships and successes. At only 7 years old, MK Leo was introduced to Smash as a game to play for fun, but little did he know that he would become the current second best player in the world with ambitions (justified) to become the absolute best. 

He comes from a loving family in Mexico where he had plans to continue with his education and study, but that quickly changed as his ability to compete and win in Smash started to take him down an entirely different route. He was always on the road, competing and fighting for his career as an esports athlete. His immediate family, who was initially a bit skeptical about his tournament-going lifestyle, eventually came to realize that MK Leo could make something of himself in a community that arguably has one of the tallest hills to climb. 

In fact, the “MK” in his name comes from the part of his family who was one of the most supportive – his brother and the store he owns called “Monster Kingdom”. His brother enjoyed playing Smash as well and also competes with the ambition to go far, but felt that he could provide MK Leo with even more support by making Monster Kingdom his official first sponsor. 

MK Leo has been competing in a lot of 2GG tournaments, which he holds with high praise, but his favorite was the Zero Saga. His third appearance in the United States was last year, where he started off with a loss and then ended up taking down the tournament in the end with first place. “Who knows where I got the powers,” he said, but clearly they come naturally. 

<hr>
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/FhX7mvE165g?rel=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
<hr>

As he has climbed the ranks of the Smash community, he makes mentioned that he continues to feel more stress. Stating that “people expect more of you” and “it’s always difficult.” Rightfully so, as fighting for that number 1 spot is going to require that you are constantly one-upping yourself and those around you. 

MK Leo and his brother say that they have one strategy: “Do things right and win.” Seems simple enough. He concluded by saying “I’m going to be the best in the world. I can and I want to.”

title: Circa eSports Brings Wolfkrone on Board
body:
Street Fighter's renowned Laura player, Joshua Philpot, known as Wolfkrone was just officially signed to Circa eSports. Circa has been around since 2015, but has a lot of key esports athletes across an array of titles. 

Although Circa has only been around only a couple of years, Wolfkrone has been a part of the FGC for many. Known for both his skill and (particularly recent) rivalries with other players in the FGC, he's certainly made a big name for himself recently. In fact, he just took first place at Youmacon 2017 this past week. 

<hr>

<hr>

So, if you've paid any attention to Street Fighter in the recent years, you've definitely heard or seen his name, but it wasn't until recently that he had a solid sponsor. In a welcoming interview with Circa as he was brought onto the team, he was asked about the overall sentiment in the competitive Street Fighter scene, but particularly about how some of the "elitist" problems (as Circa puts it) have grown over the recent years. Wolfkrone said, "I take tournaments very serious because winning means everything to me. Being in the scene many years I’ve seen players lose sight of their true purpose."

title: Is Dallas Fuel's decision not to further punish xQc setting a low bar?
body:
Just the other day, one of Dallas Fuel's team members, xQc, was banned by Blizzard for a period of 72 hours for using the in-game reporting system inappropriately. As of this afternoon, Dallas Fuel posted on their social media that after speaking with the OWL commissioner Nate Nanzer and Felix, a decision has been made to not pursue any further punishment.
With this event being the first incident since the assembly of the Overwatch League having to do with players being reprimanded for their actions, are we getting an idea of how issues like this will be handled in future cases? Is this a case where something else should have been done? Does this set the expectations for professionalism too low for players in the OWL?
One thing to take into account is that these players are no longer only streamers or players for a one off team. The OWL is an entirely new entity and as such, it needs to hold a level of professionalism that is a little bit different than others. That means that these players are representing something that is larger and more in the public eye than they ever have, so it's going to be an adjustment for them. That's potentially where Fuel and Nanzer were coming from when this decision was made.
Even off camera, using the reporting system in the way that he did, one would find that at least the ban was justified. However, now being a part of Dallas Fuel, a lot more is at stake than just his own reputation. Hopefully this will not continue to be something that is given a free pass in the future. xQc has issued an apology on his social media, saying that he "wasn't thinking clearly".

title: Mayhem v. Fusion Preseason Matchup
body:
Starting off the Overwatch League preseason matches is the Florida Mayhem v. Philadelphia Fusion matchup. There are quite a few differences between these two teams. Since there isn’t a lot of statistical data on the teams as a whole, we’re going to take a look at what’s out there and see what we might be able to infer on an individual player basis.

Team Composition

Mayhem is the only team in the entire Overwatch League that has the minimum required number of players: 6. So they better be stacked. Let’s see what we have! Although knowing each player’s home country isn’t all that informative on it’s own, we can combine that knowledge with whether or not the player competed in the Overwatch World Cup on their respective country’s team. This will give us an indication of whether or not the player in question is one of the top in the country. Of the six players, four of them are from Sweden, one from Belgium, and one from Finland. Sweden: Manneten*, TviQ*, Zebbosai*, CWoosH* Belgium: Logix* Finland: Zuppeh* *competed in OWWC So, 100% of the team competed in the world cup. These players are among the top in their respective countries, so putting all players of this caliber on the same team could be dangerous for their opponent. It’s interesting, because a lot of other teams in the OWL don’t have much more than half of their players who competed in the OWWC. This isn’t to say that they aren’t solid players (that would be ridiculous), but having the chops to compete in the OWWC might give a little more edge than one might think. In terms of roles (which can always change as time goes on), 1/3 is DPS, 1/3 is Support, and 1/3 is Flex, so it seems like they have all the bases covered, but the cohesion between them is going to have to be on point, seeing as they don’t have the ability to swap anybody out during game time. They have no other choice but to work together as a team of 6 and only 6. As for Philadelphia Fusion, there is a little more diversity in terms of player home countries, but that comes with having 12 members as opposed to 6. Here is the breakdown: South Korea: Carpe, DayFly, Hotba, SADO Canada: Joemeister* United Kingdom: Boombox* Sweden: Snillo* Finland: fragi* Israel: Eqo* Russia: ShaDowBurn* Spain: Neptuno* France: Poko As for Fusion, 58% of the team competed in the world cup. However, the players who didn’t compete do have a notable past in the competitive arena. As far as role composition, 1/3 of the team is Support, 1/3 is DPS, 1/6 is Defense/Tank, and 1/6 is Flex. With a pretty even spread for player roles, they definitely have more flexibility as far as being able to change up their meta on the fly. They have at least 2 players in each role that specialize in said roles. The flex players for both teams obviously can adapt and play what is needed, but sometimes having a solid specialty in a hero type can really make the difference. A team should be a well-rounded group of specialized players, not a group of well-rounded players (there is a difference), and I think Fusion fulfills that pretty well.

Win Rates

Now, I want to say a little bit of a disclaimer about this section before anyone takes it too seriously. Obviously, as a team there have been no competitive matches yet, so the win rates and other quantitative data as a team have not been recorded. That being said, I just took a quick look at GosuGamers and researched each individual player. I took the win rates from those player pages and averaged them into a “Team Average” Win Rate. So it’s pretty much just for kicks at this point, but once things start happening, you’ll get a full blown quantitative analysis of the teams from me, I promise. GosuGamers puts pretty decent effort into recording team and player statistics, so let’s see what we have for now. For Mayhem, these are the win rates on a per player basis via GosuGamers: Manneten: 64% TviQ: 79% Zebbosai: 71% CWoosH: 72% Logix: 70% Zuppeh: 76% This makes Mayhem’s team average win-rate at 72%, which isn’t too bad and seems to be a reasonable ballpark for high level players. As for Fusion, since they have 12 players (one of which doesn’t have any stats on GosuGamers), what I did was take the top 6 win rates from the team and calculate the average that way. Some players had some outliers in terms of stats, which would’ve thrown the average way off, but most of the players were in the same ballpark as the lower 3 players on the list I made below: Boombox – 80% DayFly – 75% Fragi – 71% Snillo – 70% Neptuno – 65% Shadowburn – 64% That makes the average pretty damn close to Mayhem at 70.8%.

Match Prediction

Taking everything into account (except for win-rates), it’s safe to say that this is going to be an interesting match. Constraints on Mayhem in regards to player availability can be seen as an Achilles heel if Fusion reads them well enough. However, I personally see it as a strength as they’re going to be focused on making things happen with the limited resources they have – making diamonds from the pressure/heat, so to speak Fusion does have more players that are specialized in their respective hero classes. For example, Mayhem does not have any tank/defense only players, only flex to fill in the gaps, whereas Fusion has the ability to place specialized people in situations that may require that extra ‘umph’. I’m anticipating a neck and neck match for Mayhem v. Fusion, but I honestly think that Mayhem is going to pull through on this one in the end. We’ll just have to wait and see!

title: 'HugS' shows us just how big #21 in SSB is
body:
From an outside point of view, sometimes its hard to gauge how big certain communities are. For example, if you like to watch esports, but mainly watch something like CS:GO or Overwatch, you'll have an understanding of how big those communities are. Sometimes, though, you lose sight of the other communities that are an integral part in making the Esports Community (ESC) as big as it is, ever increasing in size. So if you don't follow Smash Bros., here is a great example. HugS, who has been active in the Smash community since about 2004, posted some of his stats on his Twitter. He has a lot to offer when it comes to being a free agent. As of July 2017 alone, HugS has placed 17th in Genesis 4, 5th in CEO Dreamland, 13th in Dreamhack Austin, and 5th in Battle of BC 2, just to name a few of the majors.
These are some fantastic standings, and obviously he's a very highly skilled and respected player, but what about the other numbers, you ask? How many people does he pull on stream? What about subscribers? Do people even watch this stuff? Oh, yes. You're definitely mistaken if you think otherwise. Let me tell you why. Again, as of July 2017 alone, HugS' Twitch stream has 3.5 million viewer minutes watched, 600,000 channel views, 50,000 unique viewers, and 3,110 subscriptions sold. All in a tidy 261.9 hours of streaming. That's about 32 work days. If you worked 5 days a week, 8 hours a day, thats only 6 1/2 weeks of work. That's just the stream alone, imagine what else he's been up to with tournaments and offline play! Basically, he's killin' it.
Great stats, HugS! #21 ain't such a bad place to be in! Keep up the great work.

title: Coach Profile: David Pei (LA Gladiators)
body:
As we all know, coaches are the cornerstone to making a team perform at their best. They see the potential in their individual team members as well as the entire team as a whole. Their job is to dig deep and make those unique talents resonate. The Los Angeles Gladiators will need that more than ever, especially since they are competing with that other team in the LA area. Well, the Gladiators are surely grateful that David Pei is leading the way for them. Pei has experience as a top 50 semi-pro League of Legends player, where he says his interest in esports stems from, in an interview done by Overwatch Score. His love for playing Overwatch drew him to coaching opportunities for Splyce (disbanded as of May 2017).
After Splyce, Pei moved to Kungarna, which had iRemiix, babybay, and Bischu on the team, who are also a part of the Overwatch League. In fact, iRemiix and Bischu are on the Gladiators roster, while babybay is on San Francisco Shock. Needless to say, Pei has been around for quite some time and is well known within the scene for his coaching abilities. He isn't scared of competing against Valiant for the LA spotlight, either. In an interview done by heroesneverdie.com he stated that LA is the ideal place, seeing as it's "kind of a melting pot of all different cultures" and it's "the epicenter of esports and I think our team will represent them well." David Pei not only has the experience in esports, both as a player and a coach, but most definitely has the coaching mindset that will take Gladiators far. He seems to have a deep understanding of his team even at this early point in the game. We're excited to see where the Gladiators can go with David Pei carving out their place in Overwatch esports! title: Coach Profile: Dae-hee Park (Boston Uprising)
subTitle: A quick look into the man coaching the Boston Uprising
body: Former League of Legends player now turned into Boston Uprising's head coach, Dae-hee "Crusty" Park is aiming to surprise the Overwatch League with his surprise team picks. Instead of recruiting pure, raw talent for the team, Park prefers to find players who have great potential but haven't proven themsevles yet. In a sense, the players that make up the Boston Uprising could be called amateurs (at least compared to the other OWL teams). This could be good or bad depending on your point of view. Since these players are still developing their skill sets within Overwatch, they have plenty of room to be molded into a destructive force by the coaching staff. On the other hand, the team could be vastly outmatched/overwhelmed by the more experienced players in the league. One of the requirements that each player on the team had to meet is being "coachable" as Park said in an interview with overwatchscore.com. This is a great road to take with the roster since it'll truly give the coaching staff the opportunity to mold these young players into something great. Park's team picks are also very interesting since most of the players come from different cultural backgrounds. There's six different cultures that make up the Boston Uprising (seven if you include the coaching stuff) which in itself is a very difficult problem to solve and overcome. While this may seem like a move that will hurt the team more than help, Park has a different opinion on the matter. While the language problem will be a problem to overcome, Park hopes to take the different play styles on his diverse team and blend them together to perhaps come up and execute strategies that we have not yet seen in professional Overwatch play. An example that Park gives is Koreans tend to use Winston and D.va aggressively while North Americans tend to play their games on the safer side. The community and analysts have been critical on the choices that Park has made regarding the roster, but if it's one thing to take away from Park, it's his confidence. Park is very sure that his team will be difficult to beat and may even surprise people once the official season starts. Even in Park's past, he's built Overwatch teams from lesser known players and has taken them to greater heights such as the Nexus Cup and APEX. Looks like we'll find out if Park's decisions pay off when the inaugural season of Overwatch begins January 10, 2018.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: EST Interview: THE COOL KID93 talks Capcom Cup, his relationship, and the origins of his Street Fighter career
subTitle: If you get the chance to fight him, be prepared.
body:
After taking first place at the Red Bull Proving Grounds in Chicago, Marcus Redmond, who you might recognize as THE COOL KID93, went on to compete in the Red Bull Battlegrounds in Boston about a week ago. Well known for his Alex, Rashid, and now being called the “best Abigail player in the USA” by PoongKo, he’s carving out his place in competitive Street Fighter as he charges through competitions, placing high with relative ease. We had the chance to speak with THE COOL KID93 about his expectations for the Capcom Cup LCQ, how he and his wife stay on top of their game, and how his Street Fighter career came to be.
EST: Was there a defining moment that sparked your interest in Street Fighter? THE COOL KID93: So I’ve been playing games all my life. Games like Super Mario 64, WWF: No Mercy, Here Comes the Pain, etc., but I never really was a fighting game person when I was younger. The reason I actually started playing fighting games was because my friend’s mother broke his WWE game, so she made it up to him and bought him SF4 instead. I didn’t care about SF, but he kept telling me to give it a try and so I did. Day by day I started enjoying myself more and more. Then eventually I actually bought the game myself and started playing from there. So that’s how I actually started getting into fighting games overall. EST: Is there a story about the time in your life that made you want to compete professionally, or was it always on your radar? THE COOL KID93: It was always on my radar, but I was always scared because I figured the Japanese players would destroy me and it’s no point to even try [laughing]. I was also scared of players in America, too. [The] problem I used to have was that I doubt myself. Still kind of do that now at times. But then I end up doing it and being real good at it. I originally tried college once I graduated, but I felt like I wasn’t taking control of my life and doing basically what society says. I didn’t want to do it, but I felt like I had to. I never knew where to start when it came to competing as well. EST: Your wife Joy is clearly very passionate about your success. It’s rare to see that kind of support. You two are definitely a power couple! So, what's the secret to being like Marcus and Joy? Any unique challenges being a power couple in the FGC? THE COOL KID93: The only challenge I would say is balancing out everything. I work as well outside of Esports. So I have to balance spending enough time playing the game and getting in a good amount of practice, but not neglecting my wife at the same time. It’s a challenge but the more we do it the easier it is. When tournaments are rolling around she understands that I gotta play more than usual so I can practice and be sharp. EST: Has she ever beat you in Street Fighter? THE COOL KID93: We never played in SF, but I’m sure she’ll win [laughing]. No doubt. One day I will try to get her to learn a bit about the game. As long as she has the patience to deal with it [laughing]. EST: Just the other day, PoongKo said on Twitter that you were the best Abigail player in the USA and that he wants to fight you. I don’t think many people would disagree with that at this point. How do you feel about that title? THE COOL KID93: It’s an honor to think that people actually see me as the best with Abigail. But I’m not really worried about being the best with a character anymore. What is the point of being the best with a character if you don’t win nothing? My main focus is to win and do my best. Getting wrapped up in trying to show people you’re the best with a character will only give you a headache [laughing]. Just go out there and do work. EST: How do you think the match up with PoongKo would go? THE COOL KID93: I don’t really like to say whether or not I’m going to beat someone, because if they end up winning then I am the one looking silly [laughing]. We played before at Combo Breaker, but that was way before Abigail was even created. EST: You clearly have what it takes to make it past the LCQ in Anaheim, but what, or maybe who, do you think will be your biggest challenge there? THE COOL KID93: There are a lot of players that I haven’t fought before that are in this tournament. I’m going to do my best and look them all up so I don’t be surprised at what I see come December 8th. One of my biggest challenges is for me to catch on to habits and styles right away. That’s something I feel is much needed in fighting games. Or any competitive game, honestly. EST: There is a $370,000 prize pool on the line. It’s a lot of money, so I have to ask, what would you do with your share of the cash? THE COOL KID93: Lord willing, if I were to win all that money I am definitely putting some money into the church. Giving my wife some money, paying up some bills and giving my parents some money as well. Then the rest I would more than likely put into a savings account.
If you’re not following THE COOL KID93 anywhere, you should be! Give him a follow on his Twitter, he's constantly uploading videos to his YouTube channel, and is on Twitch as well.

title: Breaking down Overwatch 'Path to Pro'
subTitle: Do you have what it takes?
body:
The Overwatch League just released an update to their “Road to Pro” path, which is at it’s core an opportunity for top ranked solo queue players to showcase their talents for Overwatch League teams. There is, however, a little more to it. So, here’s the entire process explained in some detail. To really understand how this process works, we have to define a few different branches of competitive Overwatch, namely Overwatch Contenders, the Open Division, and some other leagues that participate. If you already understand how any one of these works, feel free to skip on to the next section – it all ties together in the end to define the Path to Pro.

Overwatch Open Division (step 1)

Open Division is where it all starts for players who are currently not involved in Overwatch esports. If you play Overwatch on PC and are eligible to compete in ranked solo queue, then you have the opportunity to participate in this. Once you’ve attained the rank of ‘Master’ or higher (in the most recent season), you’re able to assemble and sign up with team of players who have the same (or higher) ranking or sign up as a free agent (where you’ll proactively need to find a team by a specific deadline). If you’d like more detail on the specifics of the sign up process, how to find a team, etc. you can read their very informative presentation on their site. Otherwise, the gist of this is that there will be teams competing in all 7 regions. Currently, there are 7 weeks of competition, where you’ll play once per week, with an 8 team playoff at the end. The top four teams from each region (that makes 28 teams) will then compete in the Overwatch Contenders Trials.

Overwatch Contenders Trials (step 2)

This is, as said above, is where the top 28 teams across the entire Open Division will face off. The Contender Trials is an 8 team promotion-relegation style tournament. So, eight teams from each region will compete, four of which come from being the top four teams in Open Division in that particular region, but where do the other four come from? Well, they’re going to be chosen from the other existing leagues in the region which are not necessarily (but can be) from the Open Division. This means that you’ll either move on to the next season of Overwatch Contenders (promotion) or move back to the Open Division/other leagues (relegation).

Overwatch Contenders (step 3)

Overwatch Contenders is the highest branch in Overwatch esports you can reach unless you move on to being drafted for an Overwatch League team. It will consist of three seasons. Previously, it was the top 8 teams from each region (there were five last season), but now it is a minimum of 6 teams from each region (there are now 7). It’s unclear whether the format for Contenders will remain exactly the same, but chances are there will be some changes. This is, however, where the scouts for OWL teams will be watching closely, because if you’ve made it this far, the next step is big time play.

Path to Pro – Bringing It All Together

What you see above is each part of the Path to Pro, just broken down a little bit. The name really says it all. It very much so is a path that’s laid out for you to get to top tier competitive Overwatch. This is something that some other sports don’t necessarily have, which is exciting. The pathway is there; you just have to prove yourself. If you can do that, you’ve done most of the battle. So, if you want to be a part of competitive Overwatch on a professional level, there are a few steps to take. First, do your best in solo queue and obtain a rank of ‘Master’ or higher (easier said than done, right?). Once you’ve done that, register for the Overwatch Open League either as a team with other ‘Master’ rank (or higher) players, or as a free agent. Just be aware that if you register as a free agent, you’ll need to do the footwork for collaborating with others that are also looking for teams. If your team performs well in the Open Division, you will be invited to compete in your region’s Contenders Trials. This is where you and the top teams from other regions will compete for slots in the next season of Overwatch Contenders. Since there are three seasons for Contenders, you have multiple opportunities to make this happen. Making it out of the Contenders Trials, you’ll move on to the actual Overwatch Contenders branch. The competition will heat up at this point to a level where you and your team will absolutely need to perform at your best. All eyes are on you at this point when it comes to Overwatch League scouts. At this level of play, you will be looked at as potential members of one of the Overwatch League teams, so be prepared. Lastly, if you’ve made it out of Contenders, you’ve made it onto an OWL team and have made it to pro. The journey doesn’t stop here, though! In fact, the Path to Pro is just to get you there. Now, as a pro player, you’re expected to be better than you ever have been, finding your resonance within the Overwatch League. Since this is path is open to anyone, that means the competition will be fierce throughout the entire process. Hopefully this is going to be the most efficient way to extract the talent from all over the world, making competitive Overwatch even more exciting to be a part of, whether you’re a spectator, analyst, player, or anything else you might identify with. Once more details on this are released, we’ll be sure to keep you posted.

title: Overwatch boosting controversy gets SADO 6 month ban
subTitle: No competitive play for half a year. Ouch!
body: It was known across the Korean ranked ladder that professional Overwatch player Su-Min “SADO” Kim was selling boosting services to lower ranked players in the ladder. Despite this, Philadelphia Fusion still decided to bring him onto the roster. It was, however, unknown how it would be handled now that the OWL infrastructure is in place. It did stir some controversy when people found out he was added to the roster, so much controversy that he was promptly removed from any media that Fusion put out with his name on it. The statement that Overwatch League has put out states: “Participating in “account-boosting” schemes, wherein an individual is paid to increase another user’s Skill Rating, is contrary to these values, and violates the Blizzard End User License Agreement. As such, the Overwatch League has chosen to suspend Su-Min “Sado” Kim, of the Philadelphia Fusion, for the preseason and the first 30 matches of the inaugural season.” Which is essentially until May of 2018, effectively a 6 month ban. So it certainly isn’t just a slap on the wrist, but it did seem to take some time to make the decision. Fusion also put out a statement on their Twitter saying “The Fusion fully cooperated with the Overwatch League…” and “We apologize for keeping our fans in the dark over the last several weeks, as we did not want to comment until all the facts were discovered.” This is another interesting issue that is unique to esports that we will surely see more of as time goes on, not just within the Overwatch League, but other games as well. Although, it is hard to see how it is worth anything to the players who receive the service as their ability to play at a higher level isn’t substantiated, but to each their own. So if you’ve been wanting to see SADO play, you’re going to have to wait half a year.

title: Coach Profile: TaiRong (Houston Outlaws)
subTitle: To lead outlaws, you need to be an outlaw
body:
Do you remember watching the Overwatch World Cup grand finals in 2016 where South Korea went 4-0 against Russia? If you don’t, let me just say that the entire grand finals took just under 50 minutes, so South Korea came and conquered just in time for dinner and drinks afterward. It was almost as if they challenged themselves to get the job done in the shortest amount of time. Well, TaiRong helped greatly in leading South Korea to that victory. TaiRong has been a coach just as long as he’s been playing, it seems. So far he’s coached a few teams including NGA Club, Afreeca Freecs, and now the Houston Outlaws. A lot of his coaching credentials in Overwatch come from this year, in fact, where his teams have landed significant placement in at least 8 tournaments including APAC Premier, Overwatch APEX (Seasons 2, 3, and 4), and the Bigfile Overwatch Battleroyal. In an interview with InvenGlobal, he was asked his criteria for recruiting players and what he values the most. This was his response:
“I can quickly tell if a player has good game sense and is a good FPS player. It should be noted being a good FPS player does not necessarily translate to being a good Overwatch player. This is the fastest paced competitive FPS out on the market. Making correct decisions speedily is imperative. What I value the most in a player is responsibility. Players can always improve as long as they feel responsible for their level of play. It is hard for an irresponsible player to make progress.”
Almost surely his philosophy is the same when speaking of the Outlaws. Player responsibility is absolutely crucial for any team to perform at their maximum. So it looks like TaiRong has a clear idea of how to utilize that trait in each player to ensure that they improve on an individual basis, which will clearly benefit the team as a whole. The first match for Houston Outlaws in the Overwatch Preseason is on December 7th, facing off in a good ol’ fashioned duel against the Fuel. How will they fare? We’ll just have to wait and see!

author: Nate Chrisman
title: Ghost Gaming possibly to replace Immortals in ESL Pro League
subTitle: Will they be eligible? Only ESL will tell!
body:
Earlier in November we learned of the roster transfer of Lucas 'steel' Lopes from Immortals to Team Liquid. Now as we go into the Pro League Season 6, Immortals is dropping out as a result of “experiencing roster instability,” said CEO Noah Whinston, “due to factors outside of the organization’s control.” 

This leaves Immortals completely removed from the Season 6 standings and a wide open spot for the Pro League to be filled. According to ESL, Ghost Gaming has been offered the spot to replace Immortals barring any unforeseen conditions of ineligibility. 

Ghost Gaming is fairly new to CS:GO, only starting to compete earlier this year in April 2017, but they do have quite the reputation in competitive Gears of War, CoD, Rocket League, and PLAYERUNKNOWN’S BATTLEGROUNDS. The team has had mixed results since it’s inception, however, revamping the roster a couple of times already. 

Over the past few months, they have competed in ESL One: Cologne, ELEAGUE CS:GO Premier, Dreamhack Denver, Dreamhack Winter, and of course the ESL Pro League. Placement in these tournaments has been mixed, largely as a result of the constant roster changes. As for the most recent regular season of ESL Pro League, they placed last. 

As we are still awaiting the results of eligibility for the team from ESL as well as the team’s official confirmation, more updates are to come.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: Prophecy couldn't foresee Envy's crushing SFV victory
subTitle: Not so prophetic, I guess
body:
For their first ever title in fighting game esports, Team Envy wins the Gfinity Esports Elite Series! Prophecy took a heavy loss in a crushing 4-0 match. The final match was Envy’s Mr. Crimson as Dhalsim against Shivyuken as Laura, an interesting matchup to say the least! Shivryuken performed well by managing the zoning techniques of Dhalsim, but Mr. Crimson didn’t crack under the pressure and ended up giving Laura a few lessons in what can happen when you wake the fight in the pacifist yogi. Team Envy has quite the roster and a lot of authority in esports, having been around since 2007. They have very competitive rosters in Call of Duty, Rocket League, League of Legends, Halo, and CS:GO, and are also behind the Overwatch League franchise Dallas Fuel. However, they have just ventured into fighting games as of late, making the title victory that much sweeter.
So, our hats go off to Team Envy for really nailing down this victory and making sure that their names are engraved in the Gfinity Esports Elite Series! We’re excited to see what more is to come for these players.

author: Nate Chrisman
title: Team Liquid steals Stacked's soul in Dreamhack Winter Quake Finals
subTitle: The best defense was not good offense in this case
body: Team Liquid faced off against Stacked for the Quake Champions: Sacrifice Grand Finals. Over three maps, Liquid left Stacked with hardly no room to breathe, taking home the 3-0 victory and the championship winnings. Both teams are clearly top tier, but Stacked just didn’t have enough to overtake Liquid in almost every aspect of the game. While Stacked certainly had their strategies using brute force to claim the soul and capture the obelisks, Liquid had the cohesiveness which allowed them the adaptability to defend against Stacked in almost any situation. That isn’t to say that Stacked performed badly, however, but failing to match the level of play that Liquid was demanding in order to keep them on their toes was not being delivered. For each of the rounds, the soul was certainly changing hands a lot, which is what one would expect from a Sacrifice match. This volleying of the soul is definitely part of where the intensity of these matches comes in, but the ability to defend the obelisk once the soul is captured is really where the heat is. As said above, in all of the matches, Stacked had strategies that involved a lot of brute force, which were effective in some situations. This allowed Stacked to obtain the soul from Liquid on many occasions. When they captured the soul, however, is where the brute force method failed to keep them afloat. When defending the obelisk, Liquid was almost always in a complete defensive position, which would require monstrous effort and coordination for any team to break down. Stacked’s strategies did end up eventually working on some level, but they were always breaking through after Liquid had already gained a substantial lead, making Stacked work much harder to defend their capture. As Stacked was defending their obelisk, the fruits of their defensive labor were not ripe, as the usual gain for Stacked was only a few percent before it was stolen again. Even given the beating that Stacked took in the finals, they deserve a massive amount of recognition as they wouldn’t have made it to the finals without top level play. As far as being in the grand finals of any Quake Championship, it’s been a while for them as it has for a lot of other Quake teams. It’s amazing to see the Quake community stay as alive as it is now and the response to Quake Champions is fantastic. Much respect to all of the teams competing in this championship, to the grand finalists, and a big congratulations to Team Liquid for their victory! See the top 3 plays from the Grand Finals here!
